title: Newman Tamburino solutions with an aligned Maxwell field

title_detail.value: Newman Tamburino solutions with an aligned Maxwell field

summary:
We prove that there exists no aligned Einstein Maxwell generalization of the
spherical class of Newman Tamburino solutions. The presence of an aligned
Maxwell field automatically leads to the cylindrical class.

summary_detail.value:
We prove that there exists no aligned Einstein Maxwell generalization of the
spherical class of Newman Tamburino solutions. The presence of an aligned
Maxwell field automatically leads to the cylindrical class.

author: Norbert Van den Bergh
fulltext:
arXiv:0802.1141v1 [gr-qc] 8 Feb 2008

Newman Tamburino solutions with an aligned
Maxwell field.
Liselotte De Groote and Norbert Van den Bergh
Department of Mathematical Analysis IW16, Ghent University, Galglaan 2, 9000
Ghent, Belgium
Abstract. We prove that there exists no aligned Einstein Maxwell generalization
of the spherical class of Newman Tamburino solutions. The presence of an aligned
Maxwell field automatically leads to the cylindrical class.

1. Introduction
In 1962 Newman and Tamburino published the general empty space solutions for the
class of metrics containing hypersurface orthogonal geodesic rays with nonvanishing
shear and divergence [1]. Their solutions can be subdivided into two classes, called
'cylindrical' and 'spherical', according to whether respectively ρ2 − σ σ̄ = 0 or 6= 0. In
this paper we look at spherical solutions in the presence of an aligned Maxwell field.
We will show that no such solutions exist.
To prove this we use the Newman Penrose (NP) formalism. The choice of tetrad
and the main equations are discussed in §2, while in §3 we prove our statement. The
notations and conventions of [2] are followed throughout.
2. Main equations
Using a complex null tetrad (m, m̄, l, k) a solution of the Einstein-Maxwell equations
is described in the NP formalism by means of a) the 12 spin coefficients, which are
independent complex linear combinations of the connection coefficients, b) the tetrad
components of the Weyl tensor, which are expressed in terms of the five complex scalars
Ψ0 = Cabcd k a mb k c md , Ψ1 = Cabcd k a lb k c md ,

1
Ψ2 = Cabcd k a lb k c ld − mc m̄d , Ψ3 = Cabcd la k b lc m̄d , Ψ4 = Cabcd la m̄b lc m̄d
2
and c) the components

1
Φ0 = Fab k a mb , Φ1 = Fab k a lb + m̄a mb , Φ2 = Fab m̄a lb
2
of the electromagnetic field. The Ricci tensor components are given by Φαβ = κ0 Φα Φ̄β
α, β = 0, 1, 2. The spin coefficients and curvature components satisfy the NP and

2

Bianchi equations, which will be referred to as NP1 , . . . , NP18 and B1 , . . . , B11 , following
the same ordering as in [2].
The variables Φ0 , Φ1 , Φ2 satisfy the Maxwell equations
DΦ1 − δ̄Φ0 = (π − 2 α) Φ0 + 2 ρΦ1 − κΦ2 ,

(1)

(2)

(3)

(4)

under which three of the Bianchi equations (B9 , B10 , B11 ) become identities.
As we will often make use of the commutators [ea , eb ] = −2 Γc[ab] ec , we present these
explicitly in the appendix.
3. Proof of the main result
The Newman Tamburino metrics are characterized by the existence of a hypersurface
orthogonal and geodesic principal null direction k, for which the shear and divergence
are non-vanishing. In terms of the NP variables this translates into
κ = ǫ + ǭ = 0,

(5)

Ψ0 = 0,

(6)

ρ − ρ̄ = 0.

(7)

The spherical class of Newman Tamburino metrics, which we consider in the present
paper, is further characterized by
ρ2 − σ σ̄ 6= 0.

(8)

If this last equation (8) does not hold, we are in the so called cylindrical class. We
suppose that the Maxwell field is aligned, in the sense that k is not only a principal null
vector of the Weyl tensor (which is expressed by (6)), but also that k is a principal null
vector of the Maxwell tensor, which means that we can put Φ0 equal to 0 too.
By means of a rotation, a boost and a null rotation of the null tetrad (m, m̄, l, k), we
can make sure that the tetrad is parallelly propagated along the geodesic null congruence
k:
κ = ǫ = π = 0.

(9)

Hereby the remaining boost freedom k → Ak is restricted to boosts having DA = 0.
The NP equations guarantee then the existence of a solution of the equations δA =
(τ − β − ᾱ)A, DA = 0, implying that
τ = ᾱ + β.

(10)

From the NP equations it also follows that D(σ/σ̄) = 0 and so a final rotation
m → eiθ m exists such that
σ̄ = σ.

(11)

Newman Tamburino solutions with an aligned Maxwell field.

The remaining tetrad freedom consists now of boosts A and null rotations B about k,
satisfying
D A = δ A = δ̄ A = 0 = D B.
Taking into account the above transformations (9), (10) and (11), we can rewrite

4. Conclusion
We have shown that, in the presence of an aligned Maxwell field, no generalization
of the 'spherical' Newman Tamburino solutions exists. As the final equation shows,
applying such a Maxwell field forces us into the cylindrical class. The next step in our
investigation will be to try to integrate the latter. Although the calculations are rather
more lengthy and complicated than in vacuum, there is good hope that this class will
be fully integrable.

present investigation.
